manifest destiny a legacy of roman colonialism and its modern implications in american politics and nativ minority strugglesintroductionthe united states history is fraught with instances of violence and systemic displacement of indigenous peoples central to this process was manifest destiny a 19thcentury ideology that promoted the expansion of the us from the atlantic to the pacific oceans smith 2018 the belief that americans were divinely ordained to settle the continent fueled the dispossession of native lands however this wasnt solely a secular missionit was deeply intertwined with religious institutions particularly the catholic church through its influence over indigenous boarding schools the church was complicit in widespread cultural destruction and abuse jackson 2021 moreover roman autocracys cooptation of christianity for political ends has left a legacy of religious manipulation that continues to affect marginalized groups today miller 2022the doctrine of manifest destiny and its impactmanifest destiny was an expansionist political doctrine and a divine mandate many european americans justified their right to expand and conquer indigenous lands based on the belief that it was their godgiven duty brown 2019 this allowed settlers to engage in violent and oppressive actions with moral impunity as the displacement of native tribes was framed as part of a broader civilizing mission treaties such as the fort laramie treaty of 1868 which was supposed to protect indigenous lands were ignored as soon as economic interests such as the discovery of gold in the black hills arose us department of the interior 2021 the doctrine also had deep connections to the catholic church whose involvement in colonization extended through missionary work and the establishment of boarding schools by merging religion with expansionism the us government and church leaders justified the subjugation of indigenous peoples miller 2022 manifest destiny provided the ideological framework for what would become one of the most destructive campaigns against native populations in us historycatholic boarding schools and cultural genocideperhaps one of the darkest chapters in us history was the establishment of catholicrun boarding schools where indigenous children were forcibly removed from their homes and placed under the control of clergy these institutions were designed to assimilate native children into european american culture by erasing their identities languages and traditions jackson 2021 tragically many children suffered from physical and sexual abuse at the hands of priests a crime that has been covered up for decades smith 2021 recent discoveries of mass graves near former boarding schools in canada and the us have shed light on the extent of the abuse smith 2021 the catholic churchs role in this cultural genocide is undeniable as these schools were often funded and operated under the guise of religious charity this systemic abuse left lasting scars on indigenous communities contributing to generational trauma that persists today jackson 2021the black hills lawsuit and modern indigenous resistancethe legal fight for the black hills represents a pivotal moment in the ongoing struggle of indigenous peoples for justice after gold was discovered in the black hillsland sacred to the siouxthe us government seized the territory in direct violation of the fort laramie treaty us department of the interior 2021 decades later in 1980 the supreme court ruled that the us had stolen the black hills and ordered financial compensation however the sioux rejected the monetary award insisting their sacred land be returned white green 2020 this legal victory while significant underscores the limitations of colonial law for the sioux the land itself is irreplaceable and the us governments refusal to return it demonstrates the continued marginalization of indigenous sovereignty smith 2018 modern movements like land back are part of a broader push for the restitution of indigenous lands and the decolonization of us policies brown 2019roman autocracy and the manipulation of catholic doctrinethe connection between roman autocracy and catholicism dates back to the roman empire when political leaders saw the church as a means of controlling the masses miller 2022 roman emperors adopted christianity as the state religion using its teachings to justify their power and control over the population this manipulation of religion has continued throughout history with the catholic church often allying itself with political powers to maintain influence in the us this legacy of religious manipulation is evident in the role the catholic church played in colonizing indigenous lands and oppressing marginalized communities jackson 2021 the churchs involvement in manifest destiny and the boarding school system shows how religion has been used to justify expansion and cultural destruction under the guise of moral superiority miller 2022the second gilded age and modern parallelstoday the us is in what many scholars call the second gilded agea period characterized by extreme wealth inequality and corporate influence over politics white green 2020 much like during the first gilded age when manifest destiny was in full swing modern political elites used propaganda and religious rhetoric to maintain control the influence of the catholic church and other religious institutions can still be seen in political movements that promote nationalism and exclusionary policies this period also marks a resurgence in indigenous activism as movements like the fight for the black hills and land back seek to reclaim stolen lands and restore sovereignty to native nations smith 2018 indigenous peoples are at the forefront of resistance to modern forms of colonialism challenging the structures that have oppressed them for centuries brown 2019conclusionmanifest destiny the catholic churchs involvement in boarding schools and the legal fight for the black hills all demonstrate the ongoing impact of colonialism on indigenous communities by merging political power with religious authority the us government and the catholic church justified the violent expansion and displacement of native peoples today indigenous communities continue to resist these structures asserting their rights to land and sovereignty in the face of ongoing marginalization as the second gilded age unfolds it is crucial to recognize the parallels between past and present and to support efforts for decolonization and justicereferences brown a 2019 the fort laramie treaty and its implications for indigenous sovereignty journal of american indigenous studies 142 4561 jackson p 2021 october 15 the role of catholic boarding schools in indigenous cultural genocide history online miller r 2022 roman autocracy and its influence on the catholic church boston church history publicationssmith j 2018 manifest destiny and the ideology of expansion new york historical pressus department of the interior 2021 fort laramie treaty of 1868 official government documents white c green b 2020 the black hills lawsuits a legal and cultural victory indigenous legal review 214 6782
